turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about New Zealand Cadet Forces.
turn.1: What changed from 1979 to 1982 in New Zealand Cadet Forces?
turn.2: The role of the NZCF ceased being primarily of military training and the preparation of young men for the Armed Forces and became predominantly adventure and development motivated with a military flavour and about 50% military subjects associated with providing knowledge of the roles and functions of the NZDF.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: The new thrust was to provide “good citizenship skills” to young men under the training methods used by the Military Forces.
turn.5: Did many join the cadet forces?
turn.6: Female cadets were accepted from approximately 1978 and although the service flavour and well tried and tested services training methods and character was retained, additional training was introduced by units, which were desired by them and the community supporters.
turn.7: Did the cadets go into battle at all?
turn.8: The loss of Government financial support and turbulent social change in the 1970s caused school units to be abandoned such that by 1985 there were only 9 remaining units, including the two earliest formed at Christ's and Nelson Colleges.
turn.9: What happened with the remaining units?
turn.10: Meanwhile, the Sea Cadet Corps had increased to 17 units and the ATC to 50 in the open community units.
turn.11: Did the cadets ever come back?
turn.12: A significant development saw the introduction of Cadet Corps Units into the open community to satisfy the demand which the schools had abandoned, the first open Cadet Unit being the City of Porirua unit in October 1985.
